awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Multiwavelength Imaging and Spectroscopy of the Corona During the 2021 December 4 Total Solar Eclipse
awd_abstract_narration:
Solar eclipses provide a rare opportunity to learn about the solar corona. This outer layer of the Sun is a mystery – it is millions of degrees and much hotter than the photosphere below it. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project will observe the 2021 December 4 total solar eclipse from a vessel in the Weddell Sea, northeast of Antarctica. The observations will observe coronal structures. It will also be a testbed for future eclipse expeditions that can take advantage of observing from vessels. This is particularly important since 70% of the paths of totality occur over oceans. Team members will be actively engaged in outreach, targeting under-represented groups in STEM.

The 2021 December 4 eclipse will be observed through imaging in white light and the Fe X 637.4 nm, Fe XI 789.2 nm, and Fe XIV 530.3 nm coronal forbidden lines along with spectroscopic observations from 340 – 1100 nm. The equipment will be placed on the deck of a vessel, which will intercept the centerline of totality for approximately two minutes. Data acquisition with the imagers and spectrometers will require image stabilization and short exposure times. Corrections will be made to the instrumentation to account for the vessel’s two dominant motions: vibrations and high amplitude, low frequency motions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Total solar eclipses enable an uninterrupted spatial coverage of coronal structures from the solar surface out to several solar radii. Multi-wavelength imaging and spectroscopy in the visible wavelength range offer unique tools to probe the physical conditions of the corona?s fully ionized gas, namely the temperature, density, abundance, and motions of the different elements defining it, from the lightest electrons and protons to the much heavier iron ions. As these ionized particles are intricately tied to the magnetic field lines threading the corona, they end up defining magnetized structures through the emission produced by their excitation.

Each eclipse yields a new opportunity to explore the solar corona as it changes significantly in time. Given that total solar eclipses occur once every 12 to 18 months in different parts of the world, it behooves scientific groups, such as our Solar Wind Sherpas, engaged in probing the properties of the coronal plasmas, to take advantage of every single opportunity no matter how risky.

The path of the 4 December 2021 total solar eclipse occurred over a relatively inaccessible part of the Antarctica continent, and over the Weddell sea. While the latter offered a high risk opportunity for observing the corona, it demanded the use of vessels as observing platforms, and gyro-stabilized platforms for ensuring the stability of the pointing of the instruments at the solar corona. Two  gyro-stabilized commercially available units, namely a RONIN and Crane 3E were used, in addition to a custom made unit named the ?benepod?. All stabilized platforms were tested onboard 2 different vessels prior to totality and proved that their pointing accuracy was within at most 1 degree from Sun center despite the 40-foot waves encountered in the Weddell sea off Antarctica. Unfortunately, the weather did not cooperate on the day of the eclipse and both vessels encountered low lying clouds covering the whole sky.

The 2021 eclipse preparations, testing, albeit failed, observations were unique in many ways. They enabled us to test the use of vessels for eclipse observations under very rough sea conditions. Maps of the paths of totality throughout centuries clearly demonstrate that they fall over bodies of water over 75% of the time. Hence, developing and testing technologies for these challenging observing conditions is essential to pursue the unique value of total solar eclipse observations. The 2021 expedition also had a broader impact as it engaged an early career scientist and a graduate student. Upon their return from the expedition, team members gave presentations in their respective communities, raising awareness and the scientific thrill of total solar eclipse expeditions and science.
